channel.title: Ruby vs Python
channel.description: I've decided to try out to write some scripts just to learn a bit more but I'm undecided on what I should start with first python or ruby?

item.title: Ruby vs Python

s1gma:

can you catfudgeign dribblers end your dumb ass language war plz? im trying to retain brain cells

item.title: Ruby vs Python
item.dc:creator: @Uncalled Uncalled
item.description:
@Uncalled wrote:

[quote=“Phillipé, post:43, topic:545044”][quote author=Uncalled link=topic=663923.msg4440411#msg4440411 date=1406442686]

[quote author=Phillipé link=topic=663923.msg4440401#msg4440401 date=1406439865]

PYTHON SUCKS
[/quote]lolwut?

I say Ruby though, as much as I enjoy Python - Ruby. But don’t listen to Ashi, Python has a better syntax than Ruby ever will. I just think Ruby is more practical.

Straight up one of the more sensible responses. Python is amazing, but what it’s mainly used for at its full potential are things like BioPython, Astropy and NumPy
[/quote]I mean, I try to be as sensible as possible. It would just be idiotic to not be. However, I’ve used Python on-and-off for the past few years, so I’m quite amateur at understanding the language. A few of those links were quite informative to me, thank you After looking at some sample snippets, it really gets me in the mood to use Python again. Maybe I could possibly contact you via private message if I have some genuine questions about the language? You seem like you could be a large asset to my learning process if I may not understand something.

I’ll always get back to you on a PM eventually, it may take a couple/few days for me to see it and respond but if you need anything just don’t hesitate.[/quote]Sweet, thanks! I tend to be a fast learner, so I may not be 100% on that pm, but I might. Thanks again

Read full topic

item.title: Ruby vs Python
item.dc:creator: @lawl lawl
item.description:
@lawl wrote:

python sucks because:
this_is_retarded
python 2 vs 3 can be a pain
requiring a self argument. the whole oop in python feels like a huge hack
global namespace cluttering: want to name a variable “len” or “filter”? too bad, they’re global functions and you’ll get a retarded error if you forget this
python devs seem to think it’s the only programming language. why the arse is something called “easyinstall”? there’s no indication that this has anything to do with python. this is true for basically anything python related. instead ruby calls it gem, at least it’s easy to relate. and instead of “virtualenv” ruby has “rvm”, again much clearer

Read full topic

item.title: Ruby vs Python

item.description:
@Tree wrote:

[quote=“Phillipé, post:38, topic:545044”][quote author=Tree link=topic=663923.msg4440362#msg4440362 date=1406425372]
Different tools for different tasks.
It’s irritating seeing these languageA vs languageB threads pop up. Understand the key concepts and use the language as a tool.
[/quote]

And he’s not asking which is “better”, he’s asking for peoples opinions on what he should learn first out of the two.[/quote]

That’s what I get for only scanning posts.

item.title: Ruby vs Python
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

I would choose ruby as it was developed for programmer happiness, if you’re looking for a reference you should check out the PragProg ruby pickaxe book - its quite DRY but it teaches you from the basics to the more complex features the language offers.

I didn’t choose Python because I don’t like languages where you have to rely on relative whitespace for the functionality or when it forces me to use a certain indentation style. also you cannot safely mix tabs and spaces in Python - so one mistake and you will be scratching your head wondering and trying to debug whats wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: Ruby vs Python
item.dc:creator: @Phillipe Phillipé
item.description:
@Phillipe wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:30, topic:545044”]More chicks in the Ruby community

Also the way Python is, readability in ruby is better and so is simplicity.

def starts_with?(s) self.index(s) == 0 end

def starts_with(s, prefix): return s[:len(prefix)] == prefix

You can’t print the class in Python either.

Because that’s relevant.

Are we just going to nest codeblocks and assume the other person is going to change their preference on syntax and readability?

d…do you know… about str?

Read full topic

item.title: Ruby vs Python
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

More chicks in the Ruby community

Also the way Python is, readability in ruby is better and so is simplicity.

def starts_with?(s) self.index(s) == 0 end

def starts_with(s, prefix): return s[:len(prefix)] == prefix

You can’t print the class in Python either.

Read full topic

item.title: Ruby vs Python
item.dc:creator: @Phillipe Phillipé
item.description:
@Phillipe wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:27, topic:545044”][quote author=Phillipé link=topic=663923.msg4439052#msg4439052 date=1405959874]

nicer syntax much more supportive community.

[/quote]
Yeah, there’s a very good community for ruby programming.

If you’re bitching about the syntax comment; keyword’s aren’t as shitty like python 'elif, blocks look better in Ruby too. Including files are verbose in Python.

The little things matter, K?[/quote]

Yeah, and there’s a very nice community for python programming also, including the channel on Freenode.

I am bitching about the syntax remark, the language is modelled around readability, simple is better than complex, complex is better than complicated etc etc.

As for Python and import, read up on namespace pollution and why python has different methods of importing.

Read full topic
